I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Urban Environmental 
Infrastructure Fund1 (UEIF) under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility (UFPF), both to the 
Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Corridor  Towns 
Development Project. This is one of three projects for GMS corridor towns; the other two will be 
in Cambodia and the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR).2 
 
2.  The project will enhance the competitiveness of towns along the East–West Economic 
Corridor (EWEC) and the Southern Economic Corridor (SEC) and support the development of 
the GMS transport corridors into vibrant economic corridors. The project will transform the 
corridor towns of Dong Ha, Lao Bao, and Moc Bai into economic hubs by improving urban 
environmental infrastructure and strengthening institutional capacities of provincial and local 
authorities. Increased climate resilience through flood control measures will significantly improve 
the productivity of economic enterprises in these towns. Clean wastewater, solid-waste disposal, 
and enhanced mobility on improved urban roads will improve the environment. The project will 
provide  environmental  infrastructure,  of  which  wastewater  treatment  and  solid-waste 
management specifically will help to reduce the carbon footprint of these towns, making them 
cleaner, greener, and more livable. The project finances 10 subprojects in the three towns.3  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Strategic  economic  development.  Improved  transport  connectivity  among  GMS 
countries  has  intensified  urban  links  and  established  a  solid  foundation  for  more  efficient 
movement  of  people,  goods,  and  services.  It  has  led  to  significantly  increased  trade  and 
commerce in border districts and corridor towns. The towns and cities along the SEC and 
EWEC, which link Viet Nam with Cambodia and the Lao PDR, are well positioned to serve as 
dynamic  centers  of  investment  and  economic  growth.  Given  the  tremendous  economic 
opportunities,  the  corridor  towns  face  the  challenge  of  meeting  the  demands  for  urban 
infrastructure and essential support services which are a result of rapid urban population growth 
and  urban  expansion.  With  the  proper  enabling  environment  for  strategic  local  economic 
development, provision of adequate infrastructure, and institutional capacity to manage future 
development, the corridor towns are expected to attract public sector investments in urban 
environment  infrastructure  and  encourage  private  sector  interest  in  urban  economic 
infrastructure. 
 
4.  This project is phase 1 of a long-term engagement in GMS economic corridor towns, and 
is aligned with the strategic framework of the GMS Economic Cooperation Program, 2012–
2022, approved by the Fourth GMS Summit on 19–20 December 2011. It is also in line with the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy, 2012–2015 for Viet Nam,4 and 
supports ADB’s urban operational plan, 2012–20205 and water operational plan, 2011–2020.6 
 
                                                
1  Contributor:  the Government of Sweden, administered by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
2  ADB provided project preparatory technical assistance. ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the Greater Mekong 
Subregion for Preparing the Corridor Towns Development Project. Manila (TA 7644-REG). 
3  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
4  ADB. 2011. Country Partnership Strategy: Viet Nam, 2012–2015. Manila. 
5  ADB. 2012. Urban Operational Plan, 2012–2020. (draft). 
6  ADB. 2011. Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020. Manila.

2   
5.  Core problem. The participating corridor towns in Viet Nam face the pressing task of 
coping with the demands of a rapidly growing urban population and expanding urban areas. 
There have been major problems with the inadequate capacity of local authorities to plan and 
manage urban growth in an integrated way, operate and maintain urban infrastructure, and 
efficiently  deliver  municipal  services.  Despite  reforms  to  promote  decentralization,  local 
institutional  capacity  development  has  not  kept  pace  with  urban  sector  development  and 
economic growth. With increasing trade and traffic flows, there is an urgent need to strengthen 
the  capacities  of  the  corridor  towns  to  manage  local  economic  development  in  an 
environmentally sustainable manner. 
 
6.  Project areas. Three corridor towns were selected as project areas: Dong Ha and Lao 
Bao in Quang Tri Province and Moc Bai in Tay Ninh Province. 
 
7.  Dong Ha is on Viet Nam's east coast, north of the historic city of Hue and the port city of 
Da Nang. This corridor town is the center of political, cultural, and economic activities in Quang 
Tri Province. It is located on the intersection of National Road 1A and Road 9, which provide 
transport connectivity and easy access to the Lao PDR and Thailand through the Lao Bao–
Dansavanh border. The strategic location of Dong Ha makes it the leading regional trade and 
investment center along the EWEC. 
 
8.  Lao Bao is a border town along the EWEC, which is an important trade and traffic link 
between Viet Nam, the Lao PDR, and Thailand. The town is developing rapidly as an industrial 
township for export of consumer articles. Within the town center is the Lao Bao Border Gate 
Special  Economic  and  Trade  Zone,  which  is  stimulating  economic  activity  and  providing 
employment for local people. 
 
9.  Moc Bai, on the border of Viet Nam and Cambodia along the SEC, is a newly emerging 
destination for large manufacturers as well as small and medium-sized enterprises outside Ho 
Chi Minh City. The national and provincial people‘s committees have designated the town a Tay 
Ninh Province economic trade zone. Establishment of the SEC has attracted manufacturing and 
industry locators, providing economic opportunities to local residents and migrant workers. 
 
10.  Related policies and strategies. The government issued a policy declaration to pursue 
a balanced socioeconomic strategy through the development of key economic centers, as well 
as  secondary  cities  and  towns,  to  further  stimulate  economic  growth.  The  5-year  Socio-
Economic Development Plan, the main pillar of Viet Nam’s strategic plan, stipulated the focus of 
urban development on (i) promoting the linking of urban and rural economies, (ii) improving 
urban planning and management, (iii) developing small and medium-sized towns and cities, and 
(iv) developing economic corridors by building economic nodes on the corridors. Under this 
strategy, the functions of small and medium-sized towns are crucial in terms of their role as 
markets  and  transport hubs for  agricultural goods,  products from  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises, and manufacturing industries. The government’s strategy is also reflected in the 
water supply and other municipal infrastructure and services sector assessment (summary).7 
 
11.  Lessons. Based on the experience gained from completed ADB-financed urban sector 
development projects, the relevant lessons learned are as follows: (i) the project implementation 
schedule should be carefully assessed during appraisal, taking into account the government’s 
lengthy approval procedures; (ii) selecting qualified project management consultants familiar 
with local rules and regulations is important for successful project implementation; (iii) the 
                                                
7  Sector Assessment (Summary): Water Supply and Other Municipal Infrastructure and Services (accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

3 
number of procurement packages should be minimized, considering the workload for contract 
management, while ensuring competitiveness among qualified contractors; and (iv) advance 
action  for  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  should  be  undertaken  to  facilitate  project 
implementation  because  consultation  and  agreement  with  affected  households  takes 
considerable time. The project design responds to these lessons with a schedule that has 
sufficient preparation time, a limited number of procurement packages, and adequate project 
management support. 
12.  Special  features.  The  project  has  three  special  features:  (i)  support  for  regional 
development in the GMS (and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations) through the creation 
of growth engines in corridor towns across the GMS countries; (ii) recycling of solid waste 
through innovative materials recovery facilities (MRFs) for waste segregation, with cofinancing 
from the UEIF of the UFPF; and (iii) support for increased decentralization by strengthening 
provincial and district authorities.8 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The expected impact of the project is for Dong Ha City, Lao Bao, and Moc Bai to 
become dynamic economic growth centers in the EWEC and SEC. The expected outcome is 
adequate and efficient urban infrastructure and services in Dong Ha City, Lao Bao, and Moc 
Bai. 
 
C.  Outputs 
14.  Priority infrastructure. The outputs include (i) endorsement of strategic local economic 
development  plans;  (ii)  priority  infrastructure  investments;  and  (iii)  capacity  development, 
including a master plan for Dong Ha City. The priority subprojects in the three corridor towns are 
outlined in Table 1.  
 
Table 1: Subprojects 
Subproject and 
Location  Subproject Description 
1. Dong Ha Urban Roads  (i) Improvement and widening of around 22 km of urban roads in Dong Ha; (ii) 
construction of drainage structures, sidewalks, and median road; (iii) installation of 
lighting facilities; and (iv) planting of trees. 
2. Dong Ha River  (i) Construction of around 6 km of slope protection structures along the Dong Ha River 
Embankment   embankment;  and  (ii)  construction  of  walkways  and  a  lighting  system,  including 
enhancement of the urban landscape. 
3. Dong Ha River Port  (i) Rehabilitation of the existing wharf facility and provision of logistics equipment; (ii) 
Rehabilitation  construction of interior roads and field office; and (iii) installation of power, water 
supply utilities, and sewerage system. 
4. Dong Ha MRF  (i)  Installation  of  a  materials  recovery  facility  at  the  existing  dumpsite,  and  (ii) 
establishment of composting operations. 
5. Lao Bao Urban Roads  (i) Improvement and widening of around 22 km of urban roads, and (ii) construction of 
roadside drainage structures and sidewalks. 
6. Lao Bao Solid Waste  (i) Establishment of a sanitary landfill in a 20-hectare area, and (ii) construction of 
Management  access road and related facilities for the sanitary landfill. 
7. Moc Bai Water Supply  (i) Expansion of water pipelines; (ii) establishment of a water supply plant with a 
capacity of up to 7,000 m3 per day; and (iii) installation of water connections for 
household and commercial users. 
                                                
8  Additionally, private sector investments in dry ports and logistics facilities are stimulated by the project in Moc Bai 
and Dong Ha. ADB technical assistance has supported preparation of prefeasibility studies for these private 
investments (ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the Greater Mekong Subregion for Preparing the Corridor Towns 
Development Project. Manila).

4   
Subproject and

8. Moc Bai Urban Roads  (i) Improvement and widening of around 13 km of urban road within the town center; 
(ii) construction of drainage structures, walkways, and median road; (iii) planting of 
trees; and (iv) installation of lighting facilities. 
9. Moc Bai Wastewater  (i) Establishment of a wastewater treatment plant with capacity of up to 9,000 m3 per 
Treatment  day; and (ii) installation of wastewater drainage networks, booster pump station, and 
sewage transmission pipelines.

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
15.  Implementation support and capacity development. The project will provide project 
management support and capacity development to the executing agency and implementing 
agency. This will help to ensure that project implementation fully complies with ADB’s policies 
and operational requirements in terms of procurement procedures, construction supervision, 
financial management and disbursement, social and environmental safeguards, and operation 
and  maintenance  (O&M).  Consulting  services  will  also  be  engaged  for  capacity  building 
covering these areas. Financial audit and monitoring of social and environmental safeguards will 
be separate services. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
 
16.  The project is estimated to cost $147.19 million, including taxes, duties, and physical 
and price contingencies (Table 2).

17.  ADB financing. The government requested a loan equivalent in various currencies to 
SDR84,183,000 from ADB’s Special Funds to help finance the project. The loan will have a 32-
year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the 
grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in 
the draft loan agreement. The ADB loan will finance civil works, capital goods, equipment, 
consulting  services,  training,  involuntary  resettlement,  interest  during  implementation,  and 
contingencies.9 The UEIF of the UFPF will provide cofinancing in the amount of $1.0 million 
equivalent on a grant basis to be administered by ADB. The UEIF grant will solely finance two 
subprojects involving the construction of MRFs for solid waste recycling. The financing plan is in 
Table 3.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The executing agencies for this project are the provincial people’s committees (PPCs) of 
Quang Tri Province and Tay Ninh Province, with Quang Tri Province as the lead executing 
agency. The respective departments of planning and investment (DPIs) for Quang Tri province 
and Tay Ninh Economic Zone Authority are the implementing agencies. A project steering 
committee (PSC) will be created to provide overall policy guidance and oversee implementation 
following the objectives and scope of the project. The PSC will be chaired by the chair of the 
Quang Tri Province PPC or, in his absence, the vice-chair. The vice-chair of the Tay Ninh 
Province PPC will also serve as vice-chair of the PSC. The provincial director of the Quang Tri 
Province  DPI  will  serve  as  the  standing  vice-chair. The  project management units  will  be 
established in Quang Tri Province and Tay Ninh Province and will be managed by the Quang 
Tri DPI and Tay Ninh Economic Zone Authority. Project implementation units will be created if 
and when required (i) within the Dong Ha City People’s Committee, (ii) in Lao Bao within the 
Huong Hoa People’s Committee, and (iii) for Moc Bai within the Tay Ninh Economic Zone 
Authority. 
 
19.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in 
the project administration manual (PAM).10 The project will be implemented during 2013–2018.

7 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
20.  The project involves improvement and widening of existing urban roads; construction of 
drainage  networks  and  sewage  pipelines;  installation  of  wastewater  treatment  plants,  river 
embankment protection, and expanded water supply systems; and establishment of sanitary 
landfill and MRFs. The technology for undertaking the civil works is within the capacity of the 
provincial and district authorities. The technical and engineering designs, including the O&M 
plan, are prepared based on standard parameters to ensure the long-term sustainability of 
infrastructure.  The  national  government,  through  the  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan, 
envisions to promote local economic development and reduce poverty in small and medium-
sized towns and cities. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
21.  Economic analysis was undertaken for all subprojects with the computation of economic 
internal rate of return, net present value, and benefit–cost ratio. Benefits that were quantified 
and valued included savings in vehicle operating costs and travel time for the road subprojects; 
health benefits, reduction in flood damage, and reduction in economic productivity time loss for 
the drainage and flood control subprojects; economic efficiency of recovering recyclable wastes 
and reduction in costs of disposal for MRFs; and willingness to pay for water supply, wastewater 
system,  and  solid-waste  management.  Given  the  varying  nature  of  the  subprojects,  the 
expected beneficiaries of the overall project also constitute a diverse group. They include road 
users, the business sector, tourism service providers, property owners, and households. The 
base-case results indicate all components are economically viable with an estimated economic 
internal rate of return exceeding the assumed economic opportunity cost of capital of 12%. 
Results ranged from 12% to 30%. All subprojects were generally also viable under adverse 
scenarios in which costs were higher or benefits lower by 10% than the base case.11 
 
22.  For  four  nonrevenue-generating  subprojects  (three  urban  roads  and  one  river 
embankment protection subproject), the executing agency has to provide funds through annual 
budgetary allocations to cover the required O&M costs and ensure project sustainability. The 
financial analysis focused on historical annual budget allocations from the executing agency. Six 
of the 10 subprojects were considered revenue generating, thus financial internal rates of return 
were computed taking into consideration the level of fees that can be collected from their 
operations.  These  include  the  water  supply,  wastewater  treatment,  solid                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
waste management, MRF, and river port rehabilitation subprojects. Resulting financial internal 
rates of return range from 2% to 23%, all above the computed weighted average cost of 
capital.12 
 
C.  Governance 
23.  The PPCs of Quang Tri and Tay Ninh provinces will adhere to the transparency and 
accountability  elements  of  good  governance  in  terms  of  financial  management  and  fund 
disbursements. Through their direct participation and involvement in undertaking procurement 
procedures of an ADB-financed project, the PPCs will develop their institutional capacity to 
undertake international and national competitive bidding for civil works. Based on assessments 
of financial management and procurement capacity, the provincial and district authorities have 
                                                
11  Economic Analysis (Summary) (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
12  Financial Analysis (Summary) (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8   
limited experience in projects funded by official development assistance. Thus, the project will 
provide capacity development assistance and training programs on financial management, fund 
disbursement, and procurement procedures of ADB and the government. 
 
24.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  PPCs.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 10). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
25.  Urban poverty. Based on the household survey and the urban poverty line of D500,000 
per person per month, the proportion of poor people in the participating towns is 9.0% in Moc 
Bai, 13.5% in Dong Ha, and 22.0% in Lao Bao. The poor live in areas where they often suffer 
from  serious  water  supply  shortages,  poor  water quality,  wastewater  pollution,  poor  urban 
environmental sanitation, and inadequate roads and drainage. They have less capacity to cope 
with pollution and degraded environments. In turn, they suffer from increased exposure and 
risks due to surface water, groundwater, and air pollution, which further adds to their poverty 
situation. Through the implementation of the subprojects, the project will improve the living 
environment and health status of the urban residents, especially the poor. Poverty reduction 
impacts will be made by assisting poor people, especially women, in improving their skills and 
accessing employment opportunities through the measures included in the gender action plan. 
There will be short-term employment benefits during the construction stage.13 
 
26.  Based on the survey, households headed by women account for 20%–38% of the 
beneficiary households, of which between 48% and 63% are headed by single women. The 
subprojects will provide individual and household benefits to women. Women are primarily 
responsible for disposing of wastewater, disposing of and managing household garbage, and 
caring for the sick and elderly. Time and effort spent on these activities will be significantly 
reduced for women so they can engage in income-generating activities and have more family or 
leisure  time.  Lack  of  wastewater  treatment  and  solid  waste  disposal  contribute  to  gender 
inequities in the burden of household work. While both women and men will gain from the 
wastewater system and treatment plant subprojects, women can benefit in a number of other 
direct and indirect ways. As they have primary domestic responsibilities, improving wastewater 
disposal will ease burdens and reduce both anxiety over exposure to waterborne illnesses and 
time spent caring for sick family members as a result of contracting a waterborne illness. The 
project will mitigate any negative impacts. The  gender action plan includes measures and 
activities that will enhance the benefits to women through participatory community development, 
employment  during  construction,  improvements  in  sanitation  and  hygiene,  and  awareness-
raising programs. The design and monitoring framework and the PAM include gender-specific 
targets. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
27.  Environment.  The  environment  category  for  the  project  is  B,  as  the  proposed 
subprojects are not expected to have irreversible adverse environmental impacts; any impacts 
are easily mitigated. Initial environmental examinations (IEEs) conducted for all the project cities 
identified potential impacts and mitigation measures to be implemented through environmental 
management plans (EMPs).14 The IEEs also included inputs from public consultations. The IEEs 
                                                
13 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
14  Initial Environmental Examination: Dong Ha, Lao Bao, and Moc Bai Subprojects; Initial Environmental Examination: 
Environmental Management Plan for Dong Ha Subproject; Initial Environmental Examination: Environmental

9 
are  in  accordance  with  the  ADB  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  the  applicable 
environmental regulations of the Government of Viet Nam. At the detailed design stage, when 
the  EMPs  are  finalized  and  updated,  the  final  receiving  environments  for  the  wastewater 
treatment plants and landfill will be reviewed to ensure that local groundwater and human uses 
of  the  areas  are  not  adversely  affected.  Estimated  costs  for  implementing  the  EMP  were 
integrated into the project costs. The final EMP, cleared by ADB, will form part of the contract 
bidding  documents.  Environmental  considerations  during  design  and allocation  of  sufficient 
budget for operation and maintenance (O&M) will help mitigate potential adverse impacts during 
operation. Effective environmental monitoring at all stages of subproject implementation will be 
ensured. In compliance with ADB’s information disclosure and consultation requirements, the 
safeguard documents will be posted on ADB’s website. 
28.  Land  acquisition  and  involuntary  resettlement.  The  safeguard  category  for 
involuntary resettlement is A. Three resettlement plans have been prepared for the subprojects 
which  will  have  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  impacts.15 The  required  land  comprises 
101.68  hectares.  A  total  of  2,394  households,  or  10,005  people,  will  be  affected  by  land 
acquisition and resettlement in the priority subprojects of Quang Tri and Tay Ninh. Of these, the 
subprojects in Dong Ha City will result in 1,176 affected households (4,704 affected people); in 
Lao Bao, 958 (3,832 affected people); and in Moc Bai, 260 (1,469 affected people). A total of 61 
affected households (261 affected people) require relocation: 38 (152 affected people) in Dong 
Ha, 10 (261 affected people) in Moc Bai, and 13 (52 affected people) in Lao Bao. All other 
impacts are partial and temporary. The overall resettlement costs for the subprojects are $12.87 
million.  A  cutoff  date  has  been  established  with  extensive  stakeholder  consultation  and 
participation.  Project  information  has  been  disclosed  to  affected  people  throughout  project 
preparation and a project information booklet will be updated and distributed during detailed 
measurement survey. 
29.  Resettlement and environment documents have been prepared in consultation with local 
communities, agreeing with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and Government Decree No. 
69, 2009 which govern resettlement and compensation. In compliance with ADB’s information 
disclosure and consultation requirements, the resettlement plans will be posted on the ADB 
website. A grievance redress mechanism will help to facilitate resolution of complaints regarding 
project performance. The resettlement plans, IEE, and EMPs will be updated and disclosed 
after detailed design and cleared by ADB prior to contract awards. 
 
30.  Indigenous  peoples.  There  are  no  indigenous  peoples  living  near  or  close to the 
subproject  sites  in the three  participating  corridor  towns. The small  number  of  indigenous 
peoples in any of the subproject locations who are residing in remote villages will not be 
affected  by  the  implementation  of  the  subprojects.  The  project  is  assigned  category  C; 
therefore, there is no need to prepare an indigenous peoples plan. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
31.  Major risks and mitigating measures are described in detail in the risk assessment and 
management plan and summarized in Table 5.16 
 
                                                                                                                                                       
Management Plan for Lao Bao Subproject; and Initial Environmental Examination: Environmental Management 
Plan for Moc Bai Subproject (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
15 Resettlement Plan: Dong Ha Subproject; Resettlement Plan: Lao Bao Subproject; and Resettlement Plan: Moc Bai 
Subproject (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
16 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10

waste management in Lao Bao, and port rehabilitation in  municipal  service  companies  (water  companies  and 
Dong Ha.  waste  management  companies).  Project  management 
consultants will assist in preparation of O&M plans.

are inadequate for project management and continued  project management, O&M, and sustainability measures

ADB = Asian Development Bank, DPI = department of planning and investment, O&M = operation and maintenance, 
PPC = provincial people’s committee, PMU = project management units 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
32.  The Government of Viet Nam has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
adhere to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. The government has agreed with ADB on certain provisions 
for the project which are set forth in the loan, grant, and project agreements. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve 
(i)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR84,183,000 to the Socialist Republic 
of Viet Nam for the Greater Mekong Subregion Corridor Towns Development Project, 
from ADB’s Special Fund resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per 
annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 
years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project 
agreements presented to the Board; and  
(ii)  the administration by ADB of the grant not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 to 
the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Greater Mekong Subregion Corridor Towns 
Development Project, to be provided by the Urban Environmental Infrastructure Fund 
under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility. 
 
Bindu Lohani  
Vice-President 
21 November 2012

metadata.Keywords: vietnam, greater mekong subregion, gms economic corridors, gms viet nam projects, gms transport corridors, wastewater treatment, ports rehabilitation, materials recovery facilities, urban roads, solid wastes management, water supply, adb projects, grant 0329, loan 2969, project terms conditions, rrp
metadata.Subject: This provides the report and recommendation of the President on (i) a proposed loan, and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Urban Environmental Infrastructure Fund under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility, both to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Corridor Towns Development Project.
metadata.Title: RRP: Viet Nam: Greater Mekong Subregion Corridor Towns Development Project
